It was in 19h9, at the time of the NAEB»s first Seminar, at
Allerton House, that the first awareness began to crystallise in the
Association of the broad and powerful responsibilities and potentialities
which educational broadcasters, as a profession, must realise» Until that
time the NAEB (which had from 1925 to 193b operated as a loose association
under the name of The Association of College and University Broadcasting
Stations), had had as its major enphaois government relations and common
management problems, as was to be expected of an organization operating
principally as a protective association organized to halt the then current
decimation of educational radio stations which were in danger of complete
extinction* In the fifteen years between 1921 and Jsnuaiy 1, 1937 the
total number of educational station licenses in the U0S0 had dropped from
202 to 37o And several of these, in desperate efforts to survive, were
operating on a commercial or semi-commercial basis* The membership of
the ACBS numbered only 20 stations in 1933, and by 19bU had risen only to
23 stations after the change of name of the organization*
In the late 1930«s the NAEB, together with the U. S* Office of
Education, had filed requests for the reservation of both AM and BM radio
frequencies for education in order to protect educational services against
commercial onslaughts which they were demonstrably unable to withstand*
In its reservations of 1938 and 19b0 the Federal Communications Commission
finally set aside five channels in the "UHF” radio band (later designated
